3D modeling.info: I've used 3D software on and off for years. I figure out how to build models for illustrations as needed.

Blender.info: I'm still learning how to use Blender, but have already made some impressive illustrations with it for OpenEmu.

brainstorming.info: I've facilitated product brainstorming sessions using FigJam as well as with plain old Post-Its on whiteboards.

color management.info: I've fixed color calibration and management issues in design teams. I own a colorimeter and I'm not afraid to use it.

design critique.info: I'm happy to give and receive constructive design critique and I don't take it personally.

design systems.info: I've collaborated with design systems teams, and built my own systems too.

Figma.info: Comfortable with components, prototyping, variants, grids, and auto layout. Productive with keyboard shortcuts.

icon design.info: I've worked through tricky metaphors and pixel hinting; simple icon shapes through to detailed, textured illustrations.

Illustrator.info: Illustrator affords a level of precision that many modern tools still can't touch. It's the king of vector tools.

image optimization.info: I understand the technical strengths of JPEG and PNG, and also newer formats like WebP and AVIF.

interaction design.info: I have over a decade of experience designing user interfaces, optimizing and simplifying them where appropriate.

photography.info: This is a hobby of mine. I'm always learning about composition, but I have all the technical concepts down pat.

Photoshop.info: Photoshop lets you do unbelievable things when illustrating icons. But, for general UI design, I reach for Figma or Sketch.

prototyping.info: I've done both low- and high-fidelity prototyping, tailoring to the needs of the design being tested.

responsive design.info: I have over a decade of experience designing responsive web pages.

Sketch.info: Sketch was a much-needed replacement for Adobe Fireworks, and is still a robust design tool today. Mac-native, too!

UX design.info: I have over a decade of experience designing successful user experiences, optimizing and simplifying them where appropriate.

UI design.info: I have over a decade of experience designing successful user interfaces, optimizing and simplifying them where appropriate.

user testing.info: I've conducted both in-person and remote user testing, and know how to structure successful tests.

visual design.info: I've designed countless attractive webpages, web apps, and native UIs for macOS, iOS, Android, and Windows.

wireframing.info: Wireframing is a critical tool for quickly iterating on a design, figuring out the important stuff first.

Auto Layout (Xcode).info: Auto Layout is tricky to work with, but I've built a couple of native apps for Apple platforms with it.

babel.info: I use Babel in most of my frontend work to transpile JavaScript for older JS engines.

CSS.info: I've written CSS for years. Custom properties, Flexbox, Grid, media queries, webfonts, and more.

code review.info: I know how important it is to look past surface-level code style to get to the root of an architectural issue.

docker-compose.info: I use docker-compose a lot on my home server to run lots of custom software on my LAN.

Docker.info: I use Docker a lot on my home server to run lots of custom software on my LAN.

eslint.info: I haven't built much custom stuff in eslint, but I've written a few configs before and understand how to use it.

Express.js.info: There are people more skilled than me with Express, but I've written lots of my own middleware for it.

Framer Motion.info: I used Framer Motion for the first time to build animations and transitions on this site.

Git.info: I know how to work in feature branches and resolve conflicts. I use GUI apps for Git, like Fork or Sourcetree.

GitHub Actions.info: I like GitHub Actions because it lets you test and deploy code while being relatively uncomplicated to work with.

GLSL.info: I'm just starting out with shaders, but they're really cool (when you're not staring at a black screen).

HTML.info: Remember tables and IE 6? Ahh, the bad old days...

Next.js.info: Next.js is a really useful framework for making performant websites with all the features users expect.

Node.info: Node.js is my go-to scripting environment and I've used it for years. It's so handy to just write JS.

npm/yarn.info: I published and maintained various internal packages at Intuit.

PostCSS.info: Haven't done much with PostCSS yet, but I used it a bit on this site to try it out.

Puppeteer.info: I don't use Puppeteer much, but find it appealing for automating repetitive tasks.

react-three-fiber.info: r3f combines the best of React and three.js. The documentation is a bit lacking, but I enjoyed building this site with it.

React.info: I'm always learning new things that React can do, but I find it really useful for avoiding UI inconsistencies.

Sass.info: Fully comfortable with Sass and all the convenient features it adds to CSS.

SQL.info: I've used SQL in its various forms over the years, including MySQL, Postgres, and SQLite.

stylelint.info: I've written custom rules for stylelint to audit colors and suggest suitable on-palette replacements.

Swift.info: I've written Swift for a few years now, and have published a couple of Swift apps in the App Store.

SwiftUI.info: SwiftUI is still really early, but it's appealing! I like that Apple saw React and copied its core design.

three.js.info: Three.js makes WebGL palatable. I'm still new to it, but I'm learning a lot. I used it on this site.

Vanilla JavaScript.info: I've written JS for many years now. The newer features in ES2016+ are really convenient.

WebGL.info: I've worked in raw WebGL before, though it's been a while, and I prefer to work in abstraction layers.

Webpack.info: I'm not super skilled in fixing Webpack issues, but I understand what it does and have written simple configs for it.
